awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Louis Stokes Regional Center of Excellence: Broadening Participation of Underrepresented Students in STEM Education Using Nanotechnology
awd_abstract_narration:
The Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) program assists universities and colleges in diversifying the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) workforce through their efforts at significantly increasing the numbers of students from historically underrepresented minority populations (African-Americans, Hispanic Americans, American Indians or Alaska Natives, Native Hawaiians or Other Pacific Islanders) to successfully complete high quality degree programs in STEM.  Louis Stokes Regional Centers of Excellence in Broadening Participation (LSRCEs) are designed to serve as regional testbeds for outreach, knowledge-generating and diffusion activities or other activities that contribute to successful practices in STEM education.  LSRCE activities may also be concentrated in the development of disciplinary research institutes.

Norfolk State University, Tidewater Community College and Pennsylvania State University (lead collaborators) and other partner organizations that include the National Aeronautics and Space Administration Langley Research Center (NASA-LaRC), Jefferson National Research Laboratory Applied Research Center (JLab-ARC), and Eastern Virginia Medical School (EVMS), all active members of the broader nanoscience and engineering research community, will collaborate as part of the Southeastern Coalition for Engagement and Exchange in Nanotechnology Education (SCENE), a regional Louis Stokes Center for Excellence in Broadening Participation. 

SCENE utilizes nanotechnology and its many applications as a conduit for engaging and inspiring talented students from traditionally underrepresented minority populations.  Through guided mentoring and opportunities for research and hands-on training experiences, students will (1) pair student participants with accomplished research professionals to seed and motivate continuing research activities; (2)  sponsor student-centered research and training activities to achieve cohorts of students who are prepared and competitive for opportunities in advanced STEM environments; and, (3)  utilize its unique resources and established collaborative connections to deliver and disseminate a suite of digitally prepared products and services to users.  The program design augments an extensive summer training and internship component, with an aggressive strategy to prepare and mentor talented students as they generate portfolios and generate competitive profiles for research opportunities at national labs and federal research agencies (e.g. NSF GRFP and NASA Graduate Student Fellowship Program (GSFP) applications). 

The center will be led by multiple institution types including a historically black university, a community college, and a research I institution that houses the Center for Nanotechnology Education and Utilization in addition to federal and private sector organizations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes

1. Promote the involvement of underrepresented students in nanoscience and technology-related graduate studies and careers.

1.1 Nanotechnology training programs

Between 2019 and 2024, several nanotechnology training programs were established to encourage the participation of underrepresented students in nanoscience and technology:

- The Accelerated Nanotechnology Training for Undergraduate Students, including a Technical Conference and Professional Development Seminar (2019-2021).

- The Advanced Cleanroom Training Protocol for Graduate Researchers (2019-2024).

- The Semiconductor Internship Program (2022-2024).

- Outreach Activities for middle school and high school students (2019-2022).- Chip Camp (2022)

- High School Program (2023-2024)

These programs collectively engaged over 350 students, providing them with comprehensive training in semiconductor processing, cleanroom operations, and nanofabrication techniques. Students gained hands-on experience with equipment and applied various fabrication processes such as lithography, thermal evaporation, DC sputtering, plasma etching, and wet etching in their research. They successfully completed a project focused on the design and fabrication of neural electrodes, acquiring practical skills in nanofabrication and participating in characterization labs. As part of their training, students contributed to the fabrication of devices using a range of nanofabrication processes, including deposition, etching, and lithography. 

1.2 Outreach activities

SCENE-LSRCE outreach is focusing its efforts on presentation of annual events and workshops on topics in nano for local high school science teachers, parents and students.

- Wiggle-Bot Engineering Design Challenge (Ruffner Middle, Southside STEM Academy, Norfolk, VA)

- NSU Lab Tour (NSU)

- Engineering Design Demo (Teen Leadership Academy, Hampton, VA)

- Career Pathways into the Field of Nanoscience (Tidewater Elementary School, Norfolk, VA)

- Meet with Science Specialist (Booker T. High School, Norview High School, Ruffner Middle, Southside STEM Elementary)

- Saturday Activity With High School Students (Booker T. High School, Norview High School)

- Online engineering design lesson (Southside STEM Academy, Norfolk, VA)

- Rocket event (Classic Upward Bound program)

Micron Chip Camp at Norfolk State University for middle school students provides an inside, hands-on look at how memory chips are made. They learned about the engineering process from Micron staff and Norfolk State University faculty. We provided an inside, hands-on look at how memory chips are made so entering 8th and 9th graders explored science and semiconductors. They also learned about the engineering process from Micron staff and college engineering students at Norfolk State University.

We developed a comprehensive four-week summer research program for high school students in 2023 and 2024, focusing on nanofabrication activities. There are 30 students from Booker T. Washington High School participating in the Summer 2023 and 2024 Program. They received extensive training in lab and cleanroom.

2. Create and distribute educational materials and resources to enhance engagement and learning in nanoscience and technology.

We created a series of learning modules covering various topics, including nanofabrication. These modules feature comprehensive video-based hands-on labs, interactive activities, and downloadable resources, focusing on nanotechnology, cleanroom processes, and semiconductor device fabrication. Developing cleanroom process learning videos is an effective way to educate individuals about the protocols, techniques, and best practices essential for working in a cleanroom environment. We established clear objectives for these videos, aiming to provide both a general overview of cleanroom processes and an in-depth look at specific nanofabrication techniques.

We also developed a series of Immersive Extended Reality-based training modules focused on using scientific instruments in the Micron-NSU Nanofabrication Cleanroom. This state-of-the-art facility is dedicated to electronic material growth and characterization. The initial focus was on photolithography and cleanroom safety procedures. The interaction level could be designed to match or even exceed the level achievable during real training. The trainee could even interact more engagingly and with features that are not normally accessible for interaction. Training modules can provide a more personalized training experience, including tailoring the training to the trainees' knowledge level, job role, and experience.

3. Build and expand a diverse network of institutional partners to support the achievement of this project's goals.

SCENE-LSRCE extended the network several other colleges, more industrial partners as well as additional research institutes:

• Micron-NSU Nanofabrication Cleanroom formally joined the Virginia Nano Networked Infrastructure (VNNI) as one of four founding members from across the Commonwealth. As a core member of VNNI network, NSU cleanroom facilities became available for students as well as researchers in Virginia.

• Nanotechnology education by the SCENE program has been networked to nationwide students through the PSU CNEU website and the Remotely Accessible Instruments for Nanotechnology (RAIN) national network.

• The SCENE program activities generated synergies by collaborating and integrating with other NSF programs located at NSU, PSU and TCC campuses.

• Micron-NSU Nanofabrication Cleanroom, Norfolk State University collaborated with Virginia Tech, University of Virginia, Virginia Commonwealth University, and George Mason University to create the Virginia Alliance for Semiconductor Technology (VAST) elevate Virginia as a leader on the forefront of the burgeoning semiconductor industry.

Modified by: Hargsoon Yoon
